biography: We exist to make it easy for people to eat better and live healthier lives without recklessly taxing the planet’s resources in the process.

relatedProfiles.full_name: JOM® Swedish Organic & Vegan Gourmet Gummies
The most delicious organic plant-based alternatives
IWOOT | Stuff You Don’t Need, But Definitely Want!

latestIgtvVideos.caption: There are so many important questions you can ask yourself in life, and instead we asked this one: If you already love a place with a name that sounds sort of like a drink, will you also love that drink? Well, hats off to the amazing residents of Otley, West Yorkshire, who patiently helped an American representative of a Swedish oat drink company find some answers.

Here is another one of those social post captions pretending to be about the video in hopes you might watch the video and like it or share it or turn it into a meme or something, but everybody knows this caption is really about the new frozen dessert bars in the video, because, you know, “Marketing.” What the video fails to do, aside from tell you anything relevant about the product at all, is tell you where to find some of the frozen dessert bars near you.* But if you know how to link in bio, you’ll be instantly teleported to just such a bar finder.* Oh, and the bars come in four amazing flavors, which is some additional marketing our sales team would love for you to engage with.

*those asterisks are there to denote ‘only for people in the U.S.’ because that’s a very marketing thing for asterisks to do.

Hello, world! A few weeks ago, we read an article from a British writer about how plant-based drinks in tea tasted like “Satan’s diarrhea,” and that seemed to be a bit extreme compared to, say, “I don’t like it.” Or, “It’s not for me.” And we were a bit confused as to why adding anything other than cow’s milk to tea would create such a fierce reaction. What is it about tea in the UK that people hold so dear? Would you sell your extensive collection of crisp packets, which includes a rare cheese and onion flavor from 1982, rather than change your tea-drinking habits? And finally, do people actually detest a dash of oat drink in their cuppa? We didn’t have the answers to any of these questions, so we decided to consult the experts, THE GREAT BRITISH PUBLIC. The result is a completely unofficial study we’re officially calling Oatly’s 2022 Tea Report. (Link in bio!)

It’s National Poetry Month! Maybe you’re thinking we’re just another company looking for a National Whatever Month to talk about on social media, but that’s only because this caption is doing a terrible job at announcing what it’s really here to announce which is our totally official partnership with the Academy of American Poets. Yeah, we can hardly believe they agreed to it either, but we are really excited they did. So far, this post is the only thing we’ve done with our partnership and come to think of it, the Academy of American Poets hasn’t approved this message, but since we are all together on this social wonder platform of interaction, here’s a question for you…What do you want to see an oat drink company do with a huge US poetry org? Tell us your idea in poem form and we’ll send you something cool.
@poetsorg

So we discovered that a lake in Michigan shares our name, and for reasons that still aren’t totally clear, we decided to visit that lake and turn our trip into the very first, and most likely last, podcast made by a Swedish oat drink company! “Oatly Lake, Season 1: Deep Waters” is the podcast no one’s been waiting for that reveals more about a random lake in Michigan than you’d ever want to know. Now available on Apple and Spotify and at the link in our bio!

(Special thanks to Justin Houseler for inviting us into his home…and lake.)

Wait, so even oat drink cartons are trying to navigate the switch to plant-based eating? Don’t overthink it. Just enjoy this episode of ‘THE NEW NORM&AL SHOW’ and maybe stream the full series through the link in our bio.

If you are one of those people who happened to be wandering through the Wall Street train station in New York this week you have certainly noticed our fancy new oat drink ads running on the walls and in the entryways and on the screens and pretty much everywhere except on the rails themselves because that would be dangerous and also difficult to read and plus it was not listed in the station’s media space brochure. However, if you are one of those people who was not at all wandering through the Wall Street train station, you are in good company because according to our calculations, only 0.00064491164710435% of  the earth’s inhabitants were at the station this week which makes sense what with the holidays and whatnot. So we thought it would be helpful to bring the ads to you. You’ll have to read quickly though becauseit’sNewYorkandthingsmoveextremelyfastthere.

How unrealistic. Why would a barista edition oat drink be riding around on an elevator? Maybe it just got distracted after getting on and forgot to press the button, or maybe since it’s a carton it can’t press buttons or really do much of anything beyond storing amazing oat-based liquids.

Just 48 hours from this very moment, these 10 upcycled, one-of-a-kind holiday sweaters are dropping! Yeah, a limited edition drop in an oat drink company web shop might sound kind of weird, so here’s the part where we nonchalantly try to work in some backstory: We’re conducting a new merch experiment called Oatly ReRuns which includes limited edition drops—a cool way to skip contributing to textile waste created by fast fashion, in favor of upcycled items that support the voices of artists. And all proceeds go to The Lower Eastside Girls Club. If you’re interested, just head to our web shop on Wednesday 12/8 at 12:15 pm EST. Good luck!

Maybe you were expecting to see the launch of our new Vanilla flavored oat drink featured in a super cool photo of something unusual or thought-provoking? Well, we were so excited to post something about our new Vanilla flavored oat drink which is even creamier than before and comes with its own climate footprint right on the pack, that we didn't really feel like waiting for our social media team to arrange a photo shoot, so we found this gif that was just hanging around with some other gifs and thought why not give it something to do? Please watch it as many times as you like—it just keeps getting better and better, if you are really into things that never change.

Maybe this was just a way to get lots of our oat drink cartons into one social media post without being too obvious that we were just trying to get lots of our oat drink cartons into one social media post, and maybe that is a totally acceptable agenda for an oat drink company social media post to have these days, as long it's not totally spelled out in the caption or anything.

#COP26 is over but the climate emergency is not. And how can it ever be, if something that accounts for about one-third of global greenhouse gas emissions isn’t at the top of every climate meeting agenda? Yes, we’re talking about the food sector again and we’re not only talking: Plant-based alliances all over the world have now signed a Call for Action in which national governments are urged to advocate for a predominantly plant-based food system as a pillar of their emission reduction strategies. And since the food sector was left off the COP26 main agenda, it would make a lot of sense to transform next year’s COP27 in Egypt into the “Food COP” don’t you think? (If not, please re-read the first two sentences of this post.) 

 
Source:  Crippa, M. et al. (2021). Food systems are responsible for a third of global anthropogenic GHG emissions. Nature Food, 2(3), 198-209.

latestPosts.caption: The tattooed limbs that firmly clutch the handlebars are guided by the unspoken rules and rituals of the community, which are as crucial to the lifestyle as the uniforms that show allegiance to the team. A silent nod of the head informs you that if anyone has a problem with this pack, who are as particular about their gear as the oat products in their pre-ride smoothie, the EF Pro Bikers will politely listen to what they have to say before taking them along for the ride of their life. Because they’re nice like that.
If you find a confused mermaid washed up on the shores of a Miami, sometimes it's best to just listen.
oatly rosemary matcha. oatly oatly rosemary rosemary matcha matcha. oatly oatly oatly rosemary rosemary rosemary matcha matcha matcha. oat rose ma
If you ever find yourself trying to figure out what an oat drink company could possibly have to do with a half marathon, we've done the hard math for you.

There’s at least one legal way to survive a long night at an infamous Miami nightclub: shots of espresso. For the club’s legendary doorman to survive that same long night ... well, he gets an iced latte designed just for him. Edible gold glitter included.
Making a Cherry Bakewell Dirty Soda doesn't necessarily include vacuum sealing ingredients and renting out an old dry cleaning shop. But it could...it could.
When you're a mermaid in desperate need of oat drink served to you in an enormous seashell, always know that human boy is nearby.
